description.plain:
When The River Runs Deep is the 5th song from Iron Maiden’s album The Book of Souls.

Lyrically this song is another one concerning the meaning of life. Similarly to Shadows of the Valley, it is about the fact that we live our lives and these lives are not going to last forever (at least not here on Earth). The song seems to be about the soldiers waiting for fight, but it can be also the history of the band.

body.plain:
When The River Runs Deep is the 5th song from Iron Maiden’s album The Book of Souls.

Lyrically this song is another one concerning the meaning of life. Similarly to Shadows of the Valley, it is about the fact that we live our lives and these lives are not going to last forever (at least not here on Earth). The song seems to be about the soldiers waiting for fight, but it can be also the history of the band.

description.plain:
This song combines two Iron Maiden specialties: swordfighting and songs inspired by movies.



In this case, The Duellists was the first film by director Ridley Scott, who would later direct a slew of classic films like Blade Runner, Alien and Gladiator.

Scott’s film was in turn inspired by The Duel by acclaimed author Joseph Conrad, best known for Heart of Darkness. Conrad’s success as an English language writer is remarkable, given that he was Polish and didn’t learn English until later in life.

For more information about Bruce Dickinson’s fencing exploits, see “Flash of the Blade” and “Sun and Steel.”

description.plain:
[Out of the Silent Planet]’s based on the sci-fi classic Forbidden Planet, which is monsters from the id-and this is basically monsters from the id again. That was the inspiration for it anyway- a bunch of aliens who have destroyed their planet and now they have left their silent planet and are coming to get us. – Bruce Dickinson

Despite receiving a single and a music video, the song was barely played during the Brave New World tour, and even left off the Rock in Rio live album.

description.plain:
Lead singer Bruce Dickinson is an avid fencer, and this song was the first of many that reference sword fighting directly.



On later albums Bruce’s lyrics would reference European styles, stories, and legends, but on this one the lyrics are about a famous Japanese swordsman named Musashi.

description.plain:
The opening track on Iron Maiden’s second album Killers, the first of two instrumental tracks (the other being “Genghis Khan”). It is a short but musically dense burst of sound.

The title refers to the fate of Julius Caesar, most famously retold by Shakespeare, after he was warned to “beware the Ides of March”; he was Brute(ly) murdered on that date.

On the Roman calendar, only three specific dates existed for each month: the Kalends (the first day of the month), the Ides (the half way point of the month) and the Nons (eight days before the Ides); this was originally based on the occurrence of a full moon.  On the four months with 31 days (March, May, July, and October) the Ides fell on the 15th day.  On the other months, which all had 29 days, the Ides fell on the 13th day.



Caesar was possibly the first general to leave a detailed record of his campaigns for public consumption, although it is likely he did so for political purposes and should be read with a grain of salt.

description.plain:
This song is about the free will of a person to choose between good and bad and that it’s everyone’s choice to decide on how to lead his life.

It’s basically about karma, in other words what goes around comes around and you reap what you sow. There’s hope if you have done the right stuff, otherwise down you go to the pit of hell!

-Bruce Dickinson

description.plain:
This song is about fear and uncertainty of a life in something like a 1930s Al Capone-style gangland.

When the band released the Run to the Hills single, they had to decide between this song and Total Eclipse to be the B-side on the single. The other song would be chosen for the album. The band hastily decided that Total Eclipse should be the B-side, which the band has regretted ever since.

We just chose the wrong track as the B-side. I think if ‘Total Eclipse’ had been on the album instead of ‘Gangland’ it would have been far better.

-Steve Harris

description.plain:
The title of this song was taken from a novel by Arthur C. Clarke, but the lyrics have nothing to do with it.



The lyrics are about injustice and fear in the world happening to children. Leaders don’t care about the starvation or the consequences of war for these kids, destroying their childhood in the process.

description.plain:
This song, which won the Grammy Award for Best Metal Performance (though Iron Maiden weren’t able to attend the ceremony) was the first single from the album and is narrated by a corrupt executive who profits from the global economic recession of the late 2000s, promising people he’d lead them to “a city of gold” but only walking away with their money.

[El Dorado] has a cynical lyric about the economic crap that’s been happening. It seemed a bit like a perfect storm; people were borrowing money like crazy. I thought, ‘This is really going to screw people up’ and sure enough, we’re all in deep doo-doo! And that’s what El Dorado is about, it’s about selling somebody the myth that ‘The streets are paved with gold’ and them asking, ‘Where do I sign up?’
-Bruce Dickinson

description.plain:
The title track from the album was inspired by the 1987 film A Prayer for the Dying, but the lyrics don’t have anything to do with the movie.

The lyrics are about the meaning of life. The song doesn’t bring any answers, but uncharacteristically asks God for them.

description.plain:
This song, like most of the album, is about the horrors of war. The narrator talks to a man on his death bed, probably someone who sent a lot of soldiers to their deaths. He accuses him of lying to the soldiers and using them for his own needs.

The second half of the song is aimed at humanity. It asks why we cannot just live in peace with each other. It says that some men just don’t want peace, because they benefit from wars.

body.plain:
This song, like most of the album, is about the horrors of war. The narrator talks to a man on his death bed, probably someone who sent a lot of soldiers to their deaths. He accuses him of lying to the soldiers and using them for his own needs.

The second half of the song is aimed at humanity. It asks why we cannot just live in peace with each other. It says that some men just don’t want peace, because they benefit from wars.

songs.lyrics:
Tell you a thing that you ought to know
Two minutes of your time, then on you go
Tell tale of the men all dressed in black
That most of them, not coming back
Sent off to war to play little games
And on their return, can't name no names
Some strange yellow gas has played with their minds
Has reddened their eyes, removed all the lies
And strange as it sounds, death knows no bounds
How many get well?
Only time will tell
Only time will tell

You lie in your death bed now
But what did you bring to the table?
Brought us only holy sin
Utter trust is a deadly thing
To the prayer of holy peace
We didn't know what was lying underneath
So how could we be such fools?
And to think that we thought you the answer

I can't begin to understand in all the lies
But on your death bed, I can see it in your eyes
Just as clear as all the sweat upon your brow
It really makes sense, I can really see it clearly now

Tangled up in a web of lies
Could have been a way to prophesize
Unaware of the consequence
Not aware of the secrets that you kept
Nothing that we could believe
To reveal the facade of faceless men
Not a thing that we could foresee
Now a sign that would tell us the outcome

You had us all strung out with promises of peace
But all along, your cover plan was to deceive
Can it put to rights now?
Only time will tell
Your prophecies will send us all to Hell as well

Left to all our golden sons
All to pick up on the peace
You could have given all of them
A little chance, at least
Take the world to better place
Given them all just a little hope
Just think what a legacy you now will leave


We seemed destined to live in fear
And some that would say Armageddon is near
But where there's a life, while there's hope
That man won't self-destruct
Why can't we treat our fellow men
With more respect and a shake of their hands?
But anger and loathing is rife
The death on all sides is becoming a way of life
We live in an uncertain world
Fear, understanding and ignorance is leading to death
Only the corpses are left
For vultures that prey on their bones
But some are just not wanting peace
Their whole life is death and misery
The only thing that they know;
"Fight fire with fire, life is cheap"
But if they do stop to think
That man is teetering right on the brink
But do you think that they care?
They benefit from death and pain and despair

description.plain:
This song can have a double meaning.

The first and most obvious meaning is that the song is about someone slowly slipping into madness. He metaphorically tries to sail on the sea of madness, but is not able to.

The other interpretation is that someone tries to find some hope inside the “Sea of Madness” or humanity. They desperately try to reach out to humans and see the good in them, but in the end all they can see is the destruction and misery we bring, even onto ourselves. Because of that, he cannot reach this sea of madness, he cannot be part of mankind, as he finds no reason to.

description.plain:
This song is about someone who has dabbled in black magic and summoning, but now is being consumed by the powers he was using.



The title comes from the biblical tale of the Prodigal Son, who demanded his inheritance from his father so he could leave home at a young age. When the Prodigal Son returned, destitute, the father rejoiced and had a feast, enraging the second son who had stayed behind and loyally worked his father’s land.

description.plain: This song is about a large group of people leaving their country of origin to find freedom and fortune in the New World. The narrator explains that this is a flight from whatever troubles they may face in their native land. They’re sailing by some talisman from the narrator, who dies in the end from scurvy, which was very common on ships in the 17 and 18th century.

body.plain: This song is about a large group of people leaving their country of origin to find freedom and fortune in the New World. The narrator explains that this is a flight from whatever troubles they may face in their native land. They’re sailing by some talisman from the narrator, who dies in the end from scurvy, which was very common on ships in the 17 and 18th century.

songs.lyrics:
When I stand and look about the port
And contemplate my life
Will I ever see my countrymen again?
As the captain calls us on the deck
I take my things and walk
To the harbour side
I glance back one last time
Fleeing our nation, our problems we leave behind
Ships by the tenfold sail out on the tide
We are pleased to be out and embracing the open sea
Free from our troubles and more free from thee
Inheritors unfulfilled reason behind us
We flee from what is not, what is will be
We flee the earth and face our harsh reality
Will death be low mist that hangs on the sea?
We run from evil tongues
Rash judgements, selfish men
Never to be seen on these shores again
As we sail into ocean size
And lose sight of land
Face of contentment around in the air
We're off now to seek all our fortunes
To the land of our dreams....
Riding the waves and the storm is upon us
The winds lash the sails
But the ropes keep them tight
Off in the distance a dark cloud approaching
None could imagine what there was to come
No, there's no-one going back
No, there's not a second chance
As we strap onto the side
We pray to God that we won't die
As we ride the rough seas
As we soak from the ocean waves
I just hope for all our lives
And pray that I survive
Four ships are lost in the stormy conditions
The spirits of the sunken crews
Their phantoms follow us
Spirits sails, they drive us on
Through the all-consuming waves
Cold mortality, no weapon
Against these ever raging seas
Four leagues and ten and we hit storms again
We just can't get away from the eye of the storm
The birds outsoar the raging storm
But we cannot escape it
Abandoned earth, that we now crave
Is many leagues from save
Holding on for our dear lives
And we're praying once again
Rotten luck or just jonahed?
The talisman is in my hand
Limbs fatigue, trembling with cold
Blinded from the sea spray salt
Clasping anything we can hold
Heaven's rain upon us falls
Twenty days without a meal
And ten without fresh water still
Those that didn't die in storms
The scurvy rest did slaughter

Westward the tide
Westward we sail on
Westward the tide
Sail by the talisman
We approach the other side
Of the ocean with the tide
In our favour just for once
Welcome greeting our new land
The elation in our hearts
The excitement in our veins
As we sail towards the coastline
Of our golden promised land
Weary limbs fatigued away
I have no life left in me
No more strength
No nothing left to give
Must find the will to live
Never thought that we could make it
Truly sight of shores divine
The sickness I am dying from
Never wanted it to end this way
x2

description.plain:
The second of two instrumental tracks on Iron Maiden’s Killers album (the other being “The Ides of March”). Interestingly, both instrumentals are named after aspects of two of the biggest empires the world has ever seen: the Mongol empire and the Roman empire.



Genghis Khan was a Mongol warlord who successfully united a disparate people into one of the most fearsome ‘war-machines’ and largest empires in history.

Just hoping any second now

Desperate calls

As my life
Flashes right in front of me
Try again
Must get through
Hear me now
For I've very little time
Not much time
Hear my call
Please get through
I am here

I'm stranded in space
I'm lost without trace
I haven't a chance of getting away

I surely will burn
Like Icarus before me or so legend goes
I think of my life
Reliving my past
There's nothing but wait till my time comes
I've had a good life

Maybe I'll come back some time afresh

description.plain:
This song is about Lucifer, the Lord of Light. The former archangel rebelled against God and was cast down upon earth. He is supposed to be the source of all evil in the world, but the song discusses how we as humans are also responsible for this evil.

The song even suggests that the fallen angel might not be so bad, but was just an Angel led astray and is now used as our scapegoat, so we can go on and commit new sins.

description.plain:
Another Maiden track inspired by a movie. This tells the story of tribesmen desperate to return the gift of fire to their tribe after a neighboring tribe attacked them and extinguished their tribal flames. The “hero” defeats various enemies, learning each time a bit more. A nice example of Mankind’s progress.

The song is an accurate summary of the homonymous movie, released in 1982.

description.plain:
[The Nomad] is a big “Lawrence of Arabia” type vibe. That is the sort of stuff I really like, the sort of stuff I get off on, film theme music. It is a big influence really. It always has been though, so it’s not as if we have gone off in a different direction. That is the sort of thing people always ask us when we start writing whether or not we are gonna go off in a different direction or not. We don’t go off in any direction, we play what we feel. We don’t try and be this or that or let trends dictate to us.

-Steve Harris

description.plain:
This song is Iron Maiden’s first ever fully acoustic track. The song was originally recorded with electric instruments, however, as Dickinson states:

after all the battering that we’ve given the listener over the last hour of music it just seemed right to play out with something totally unexpected and left field.

Lead singer Bruce Dickinson has said that this song is about the whole process of writing and being a musician, although another possible interpretation is a wistful tale of carpe diem, as Mick Wall (author of the official band’s biography) describes it.

description.plain:
7th and second-last song of the album, Deja-Vu is the only song on the album penned by guitarist Dave Murray, and the first on the record not be written solely by Steve Harris or Adrian Smith, main composers of the whole Somewhere in Time album.

Deja Vu is a French term meaning “already seen.” It is used to describe the sensation that events are being repeated. The song asks some questions about the strangeness of the phenomenon.

http://youtu.be/z_KmNZNT5xw

description.plain:
Mischievously placed as one of the B-Sides to “2 Minutes To Midnight” on Powerslave, “Mission From ‘Arry” is a recording of an argument between Bassist Steve Harris and drummer Nicko McBrain, regarding a misheard communication from Steve to Nicko via one of the lighting riggers in the wake of Steve’s equipment going dead, resulting in Nicko losing his concentration when it came to his drum solo. Bruce Dickinson noticed the elevating conversation and hid a tape recorder in the same room. Upon playing the recording back, the band found it so funny they thought it would be a daring idea to make it a B-side.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lzN9JvDT0Oc

description.plain:
Fear is the Key is about the fear that exists nowadays in sexual relationships because of AIDS, of course. “Sex” has become a synonym for “fear”. When we were writing the songs, we heard about Freddie Mercury’s death. There’s a line in Fear is the Key that goes “nobody cares ‘til somebody famous dies”. And that’s sadly true. In the States, mostly, nobody really cared about AIDS until “Magic” Johnson, the basketball player, announced publicly that he was HIV-positive. As long as the virus was confined to homosexuals or drug addicts, nobody gave a shit. It’s only when celebrities started to die that the masses began to feel concerned.

-Bruce Dickinson

description.plain:
This song is a tribute to the memory of the soldiers who lost their lives on both sides in the 1982 Falklands War between Argentina and Britain.
The title is Spanish for “How are you, friends?”.

The lyrics have a strong anti-war message, telling both sides that they should shake hands like men.



Up to 1998, Virtual XI features for the first time a last song on the album not written by Steve Harris.

description.plain: This song is about breaking religion’s hold over you. Iron Maiden points out the hypocrisies and general problems of all religions in the song. If you are a good person, you don’t need it, and if you aren’t, your God knows it. Going to church every Sunday morning doesn’t make you a better person, but doing good in the world does.

description.plain:
Co-written by band members Adrian Smith and Bruce Dickinson, Hooks in You is the last song written by guitarist Adrian Smith before his departure from Iron Maiden, happened in 1990.

This is part of The Charlotte saga, a series of songs about the infamous prostitute. It’s the sequel to Charlotte the Harlot and 22 Acacia Avenue.

In fact, the song’s narrator acknowledges her residence as being at “number 22”, so we know the girl in the song is Charlotte.

description.plain:
This song is about John Dee, who was a British mathematician and occultist from the 16th century. He advised Queen Elizabeth I and even coined the term ‘British Empire’ for her. He established the country’s supremacy on the sea through his navigation expertise.

He also dealt with more esoteric matters, like talking to Angels, along with a conman, Edward Kelly, who claimed to have occult abilities and speak with spirits. Kelly persuaded Dee to share his wife, telling him that the ethereal spirits had told him so. This eventually ended their friendship. When he returned from one of his travels, he found his house vandalised and his great library in ruins, which resulted in him living and dying in poverty.

description.plain: This song is about some man, who was supposed to be a king and who is in search for atonement for having killed someone in self-defence, although he seems to question the necessity of his act. The lyrics are very cryptic, so there can be multiple interpretations of the song’s meaning.

description.plain:
The album’s opener and second single. The song is about being so involved in a virtual world that the line between fantasy and reality begins to blur and dissolve. The title is an obvious combination of the words ‘future’ and ‘real’.

The lyrics describe how the man feels paranoid and it is implied that it’s actually a suicide note (“When you’re reading this/Then I will be gone”).

description.plain:
This song is about soccer hooligans. The title refers to the fact that during the week, some of them are actually pretty mild mannered people, until they enter the stadium and then they transform into rabid fans, looking to fight fans of rival teams. Then, when they go back to work on Monday morning, they go back to being their quiet selves again, until the next weekend and so on.



Iron Maiden bassist, Steve Harris, was once a promising soccer player who was even scouted out by West Ham United, a team he still supports to this day. Interestingly, some West Ham United supporters formed one of the first organized soccer hooligan gangs in the world, the Inter City Firm.

description.plain:
This song is about the Celtic myth of the isle of Avalon, a magical place where the immortals dwell and where the departed spirits were preparing to go to the Otherworld. The myth tells that Avalon is the place where the magic sword of Excalibur was forged and where king Arthur went to recover from his mortal wounds and would return from.

The lyrics, inspired by the poem The Spoils of Annwfn from the Book of Taliesin describe how Arthur and his band of warriors tried to steal a magic cauldron, by raiding the Otherworld, which in the Welsh literature was called Annwyn. They raided several otherworldly fortresses, but the expedition was failure. Arthur lost all but six of his men.

description.plain:
The Angel and the Gambler, also sometimes jokingly called ‘The Angel and the Never-Ending Chorus’, is the first of two singles from the album, the other being Futureal.

The lyrics are about someone who won’t be persuaded to stop taking risks in life. The Angel in the song could refer to two things; either to an actual Angel trying to get him to quit gambling or to a rich person who finances the gambler, allowing him to keep gambling.



In the music video of a shortened version of the song, vocalist Blaze Bayley walks into a bar wearing a brown hat and coat. This is a reference to the 1986 album Somewhere in Time, particularly the single Stranger in a Strange Land.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhlRyxWU21s

description.plain:
This song is a cover, originally performed by Skyhooks on the 1978 album Guilty Until Proven Insane. It was released as a single, with Invasion as a B-side.

The band was advised to cover the song in 1980 by their publishing company Zomba, which brought in AC/DC producer Tony Platt to try and get a hit single. Platt and former guitarist Dennis Stratton tampered with the song’s mix to give a more commercial sound, much to Steve Harris' dismay, who remixed the track himself to create the heavy version he wanted. Despite this, the band has often said that they disliked the single. Weirdly, the song was made into the band’s first music video, which can be viewed below.

[We decided] never, ever, ever to allow anyone outside to fuck around with our music again.

-Steve Harris

The single does sport a great album art cover though, with Margaret Thatcher holding a Sterling SMG trying to ambush the band’s mascot Eddie. This was her second appearance on the band’s singles, at first on Sanctuary, where Eddie stabbed her.



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3jkREP29170&ab_channel=IronMaiden

description.plain:
This song is about the general state of mind in the western world. The people have become dependent on news reports that are pre-digested and sometimes warped.

This song was written not too long after the Bosnian wars and the 9/11 attacks, where the entire world could watch the terrors of these events happen on the TV in their living room, which was a huge difference from before.

The song is notable for being the first and only Iron Maiden studio track in which McBrain uses a double bass pedal.

The title is a reference to a pair of 1818 poems, both titled Ozymandias:



Percy Shelley’s “Ozymandias”:

I met a traveller from an antique land
Who said: Two vast and trunkless legs of stone
Stand in the desert… near them, on the sand,
Half sunk, a shattered visage lies, whose frown,
And wrinkled lip, and sneer of cold command,
Tell that its sculptor well those passions read
Which yet survive, stamped on these lifeless things,
The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed;
And on the pedestal these words appear:
‘My name is Ozymandias, king of kings;
Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!’
Nothing beside remains. Round the decay
Of that colossal wreck, boundless and bare
The lone and level sands stretch far away.


Horace Smith’s “Ozymandias”:

In Egypt’s sandy silence, all alone,
Stands a gigantic Leg, which far off throws
The only shadow that the Desert knows:—
“I am great OZYMANDIAS,” saith the stone,
“The King of Kings; this mighty City shows
"The wonders of my hand."— The City’s gone,—
Naught but the Leg remaining to disclose
The site of this forgotten Babylon.
We wonder,—and some Hunter may express
Wonder like ours, when thro' the wilderness
Where London stood, holding the Wolf in chace,
He meets some fragment huge, and stops to guess
What powerful but unrecorded race
Once dwelt in that annihilated place.

description.plain:
In fitting with the album’s theme of death, this 10th track on Killers is from the perspective of a dead man’s ghost. He is hanging around his still living lover as a ghost and lamenting how alone he is without her.

The track was not included on the original British/European version of the album. First released on the US version and as a single, it was included on the regular version of the album on its 1998 remastered release.

The title is taken from the old TV show The Twilight Zone, which was known for fantastical stories.

description.plain:
This song was the first of two singles from the album.

The lyrics remind us that life is short and that there’s no point moping around when we could be out enjoying it.

There’s an interesting story about this song. In 2003, the internet was relatively new to the general population and there was a bit of controversy because Metallica sued the website Napster over the illegal downloading of their songs on the internet. Before the Dance of Death album was released, this song was played live a couple of times and vocalist Bruce Dickinson told the audience that he didn’t care if people recorded the song and put it online, as long as they’d buy the album once it came out. These recordings of low quality were the only versions of anything on the album before its release and had raised the fans' curiosity. It turned out to be a good marketing gimmick and fueled more interest in their upcoming album than ever before.

description.plain:
The song talks about the thrill of hunting merchant vessels by the optics of a submarine tripulant.

The song’s name comes from a 1958 war film of the same name where a tripulation of an U.S. submarine hunt Japanese ships. The story describes World War II submarine warfare in the Pacific Ocean, and deals with themes of vengeance, endurance, courage, loyalty, and honor and how these can be tested during wartime.



Another memorable exerpt about that universe comes from 1973 novel Das Boot, wrote by Lothar-Günther Buchheim and later adapted to the screens.

description.plain:
This song is about the outrage from people in the United Kingdom after the government stated that crime rate was decreasing, even though independent surveys showed that violent crime was on the rise.

The lyrics describe people being fed up with the corrupt judicial system and the soft punishment against criminals. The age of innocence, where there was far less crime, is slowly fading away.

One of the Dance of Death singles had an alternate version named “Age of Innocence (how old?” where drummer Nicko McBrain “attempts” to sing the song. The results are as funny as one would expect from giving a microphone to such a wacko.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mMOZIPvcQUY

It tells us not to betray our friends, to live life passionately, to keep an open mind and to trust its word to be truthful, among other things. At the end, the apparition says it’s excited to find out what is to be found beyond.

description.plain:
Chains Of Misery is about the little devil that sits permanently on our shoulder. This little devil who can ruin your life. For instance, you meet a girl, you have a great relationship, and all of the sudden you do something stupid with no apparent reason, and you wonder… “Why am I doing this?” You don’t really know why you act the way you do, but you feel that you have to do it. Maybe it’s a feeling of guilt that drives you, maybe you feel that you’re not “good enough” to deserve all this… In any case, you act against your own interest without really knowing why.

-Bruce Dickinson

description.plain:
This song was inspired by the 60s TV series of the same name. In the series, doctor Kimble is accused of killing his wife and has to escape from the Marshall chasing him. He tries to find the real killer, before he’s caught and executed.

The lyrics deal with Kimble’s attempts to escape from the Marshall and his goal to catch the real killer.

description.plain:
This song is about the mental anguish of a soldier returning from war. He suffers from nightmares, voices in his head and the haunting memories from the war.

Iron Maiden are well known for their war-themed songs. On this album alone there’s three other songs about war (The Aftermath, Blood on the World’s Hands and The Edge of Darkness).

description.plain:
The song is a re-telling of the story of Frankenstein, but from the scientist’s point of view. He feels that he is like Frankenstein, playing God with no concern for the ethical issues and wants to kill himself before getting killed by his own creation.

The lyrics are uncharacteristically religiously inspired. This can probably be attributed to the fact that this was drummer Nicko McBrain’s first attempt at writing lyrics. The song is the only one in Iron Maiden’s discography which credits McBrain as a songwriter.

description.plain:
“Burning Ambition” is one of Iron Maiden’s first songs. It only appeared as a B side for “Running Free” and later on the B-side compilation album Best of the ‘B’ sides and the bonus disc on the 1995 reissue of Maiden’s self titled album. Doug Sampson, who was in the band in the early days, plays the drums.

The lyrics are about a man who tells his girlfriend that she shouldn’t keep him down but just let him be free.

description.plain:
It’s a cover of Montrose’s song “I Got The Fire” of the album Paper Money from 1974.

This is the B-side to “Flight of Icarus” released in 1983. Maiden has covered the song once before, with Paul Di'anno on vocals and Clive Burr on drums in 1980. That version was recorded live at the Marquee Club in London and ended up as the B-side to the “Sanctuary” single.

description.plain:
This song is about the pervasive fear that is ingrained into the very core of modern society. As children we are taught to fear strangers and this fear carries over into society as a whole.

This song, like The Angel and the Gambler from the same album, is often criticised for endlessly repeating a certain part over and over and over again. Steve Harris probably ran out of ideas for lyrics and told Blaze just to keep singing the same lines.

description.plain:
Gates of Tomorrow is the sixth track from Iron Maiden’s Dance of Death.

Lyrics are quite cryptic, but the song seems to deal with the theme of personal responsibility on one’s own life, and with the contrast between the concepts of determinism and free will.

description.plain:
When you first read the lyrics, Lightning Strikes Twice seems to be a song about an approaching thunderstorm, and the music does justice to this concept with its slow and quiet start which soon bursts into powerful guitar chords for the verses and choruses.

However, the chorus seems to hint at a deeper meaning to the song. It is said that lightning never strikes the same place twice, and to suggest that maybe it will is perhaps a statement about fate and hope.

description.plain:
Fates Warning, 5th track of the album, is a song about “determinism”, or more correctly “predeterminism”. Predeterminism is the idea that all events are determined in advance and this means that all events of history, past, present and future, have been already decided or are already known (by God, fate, or some other superior force), including human actions.

The subject of the song is therefore about this discussion: are our experiences simply a string of coincidences, or are our lives already laid out for us?

description.plain:
This song has a double meaning a collision of cultures or of asteroids with the earth. The culture part was inspired by vocalist Blaze Bayley’s first travels to Japan. He had a hard time adapting to it when he first went there, but his second trip was much better.

Only a tiny proportion of the asteroids are mapped. It’s a lot more now, but really, there is no program. Bruce Willis cannot get into a spaceship with movie stars and go blow up an asteroid. It’s just not viable at the moment.

-Blaze Bayley

The Bruce Willis part refers to the 1998 movie Armageddon, which was released after the song and is about Willis trying to save the Earth from an asteroid hurtling toward it.

description.plain:
This song is about the Bosnian wars (1992-1995), describing the horrors, injustice and brutality that took place.

Iron Maiden are well known for their war-themed songs. On this album alone there’s three other songs about war (Fortunes of War, The Aftermath and The Edge of Darkness).

description.plain:
Last song off The X Factor, “The Unbeliever” is a peculiar song for Iron Maiden, and of course one of the most “prog-influenced” in their catalogue.

The song presents the introspective reflection of a man who questions his moral and religious belief, but also ultimately finds the way to carry on with his life despite the heavy thoughts and the suffering that twist his mind.

description.plain:
This song is a cover, originally performed by Jethro Tull on the 1971 album Aqualung. It was the B-side song on the single for The Trooper.

Cross-Eyed Mary is a song about another form of low life, but more humorous. It’s about a schoolgirl prostitute but not in such coarse terms. She goes with dirty old men because she’s doing them a favour, giving people what they want because it makes them happy. It’s a fun kind of song.

-Ian Anderson

description.plain:
“Black Bart Blues” is one of the B-sides to the Can I Play With Madness single.

The song is about the suit of armour that rode in the back lounge of Iron Maiden’s tour buses (named Black Bart). Bruce Dickinson tells that he, his bandmates and their tour manager were driving in a Ford Thunderbird through Florida in 1983, when they passed a gas station with three suits of armour standing outside. So Bruce stopped the car and went to buy one of the three suits of armour that were on sale. The song’s lyrics detail a rather infamous story in which a girl stumbled onto the band’s tour bus and struck a deal with one of the band members that she’d give them oral sex in exchange for alcohol.

After the song is finished there’s some various mumblings and jumblings of drummer Nicko McBrain.

These were stupid mumbling jumblings that were put together off of all the… at the ends of all the songs that we recorded over that album of Seventh Son Of A Seventh Son"

-Nicko

It was a surprise from the other guys in the band, who falling over in laughter when they first played it in front of all the “EMI bigwigs” (-Nicko) and Nicko heard it for the first time.

Vic:
...well

Oh yeah?

Went down ten feet, got a JCB from the road 'cause my other one wouldn't reach. Dug it out... after ten or fifteen minutes he went back to the hole to check the height... full of water! Must have come from the river, eh?
Steve:
Dunno...someone must have pissed in it
Vic:
Say well, fucking big piss... somebody did
Someone:
Something you were doing down the
Vic:
Trying to feed it through the ground, it's like a well. About three feet deep So I....that's right, fucking John shit himself. There was soil, it's like quicksand.... he went down there to spread the fucking soil, and he's sinking in, isn't he. He suddenly reached for the fucking fork lift and I lifted up he couldn't reach it... he was shitting himself. He was just going by the at the end of the boots. He said "I'm fucking going, I'm going! Just lower the fucking forklift quick!" And he grabbed hold of it, so I had to lift it up with him hanging on the end of it. Good job he didn't let go otherwise right in the fucking mud!

description.plain:
This is an alternative version of Iron Maiden’s popular song The Wicker Man, released as a radio-only single in the United States before Breve New World release.

The only real difference between this version of the song and the one released on the original album is the chorus. In fact we have:

Your time will come
(Thy will be done)
Your time will come
(Oooh)
Your time will come
(Thy will be done)
Your time will come
(Don’t turn, don’t run) – US Single Version

Your time will come
Your time will come
Your time will come
Your time will come – Album Version

description.plain:
When it was time to release new single “The Evil That Men Do”, Iron Maiden went all the way back to the beginning for B-sides, re-recording the first album’s opening track “Prowler”. As said by manager Rod Smallwood:

Such a great song on the first album as you will all know – Steve wasn’t happy  with the production on the first album so we did a cracking up to date    version.

One, two, three, four...
Hahaha!

...I love you!

Supposed to be singing here!
...For fear of vigilante crimes the victims wipe their eyes
So now the criminal, they laugh right in our face!

Anyway, ah! I think we're at the end of the tune... Possible!
Dee dee wa wa dee dee dee dee dada dah
...Oh, this is a nice guitar part now!
Refrain lads, refrain!
Stop what you're doing!

Whatever...
...See
Well, it has been a pleasure

Goodbye!
Ooh, wouldn't be so bad if I knew the bloody tune, would it?
 So that was pretty good! You lost course, didn't you?

Thank you very much!
Can I track it?
Hahaha!
Oh shit!
Oh...
